title: 103_s2061
content: Title V of the Small Business Investment Act of 1958 is amended to include a new section allowing for the prepayment of development company debentures. The Small Business Investment Act of 1958 is amended to allow for the prepayment of development company debentures purchased by the Federal Financing Bank and guaranteed by the Administration. The borrower can prepay by paying the unpaid principal balance plus accrued interest and a repurchase premium. The Administration will cover the difference in the repurchase premium paid. The Small Business Investment Act of 1958 allows prepayment of development company debentures purchased by the Financing Bank. The borrower can prepay by paying the unpaid principal balance, accrued interest, and a repurchase premium calculated based on the debenture's interest rate and a specific factor. The Small Business Investment Act of 1958 allows prepayment of development company debentures purchased by the Financing Bank. Prepayment percentages vary based on the term length since original issuance, ranging from 1.00 for a 10-year term to 0.60 for a 25-year term. The Small Business Investment Act of 1958 allows prepayment of development company debentures purchased by the Financing Bank. Prepayment percentages vary based on the term length, ranging from 1.00 for a 10-year term to 0.04 for a 25-year term. The Small Business Investment Act of 1958 allows prepayment of development company debentures under specific requirements. These include ensuring the debenture is not in default, using state or personal funds for prepayment, and certifying that benefits are passed through to the borrower. No additional fees or penalties can be imposed beyond those specified in the Act. The Small Business Investment Act of 1958 allows refinancing of debentures under specific conditions, with limitations on the amount for prepayment. The borrower has the option to exercise the provisions of the Act, including new credit or spending authority. No job creation requirement is needed for refinancing under this Act. The Small Business Investment Act of 1958 allows refinancing of debentures with limitations on prepayment amounts. The borrower has the option to access new credit or spending authority, subject to appropriations Acts. Appropriations are authorized as necessary. The Administration must establish regulations within 30 days, including a priority order. Subsection 504(b) is repealed, subsection 504(a) is renumbered, and paragraphs (1) through (3) are renumbered as subsections 504(a) through (c).
